Japan, which to its credit has never subscribed to
the theory a nation can sell without buying, does
hold to the idea that the world owes this nation a
living— and that in between struggling with import
permits and customs red tape foreign businessmen
should be ever willing and happy to help Japan when
necessary.
Such are a few of the criticisms which may fairly
be leveled against this country if the comparison is
made with the procedures and outlook of the West.
If the comparison is with other Asian nations, which
constitutes a more accurate and. reasonable yardstick,
then Japan shows up as a modern and advanced nation
and one with an enviable record for profits in its
international dealings.
The most remarkable single fact about postwar Japan
is the degree of success with which an additional
fifteen million people are being provided for—
somehow and with no unemployment crisis— with ex¬
ports still running well below prewar levels. The
next most remarkable fact is that, despite low in¬
comes, rising prices, and an acute shortage of
